Process Modeling Experience Finance Manager Stanford University February 2013  –  October 2014  (1 year 9 months) Stanford, CA The Walter H. Shorenstein Asia-Pacific Research Center (Shorenstein APARC) is a unique Stanford University institution focused on the interdisciplinary study of contemporary Asia. As a Finance Manager at Shorenstein APARC at Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies, my responsibilities include: 
 
• Financial forecasting to assure that the Center is meeting budget goals and recommending budget modifications to meet goals. 
• Financial forecasting for various center revenue sources and expenses. 
• Preparing Center’s annual budget and entering it into the University’s system. 
• Managing mid-year variance reporting and participating in fiscal year-end close. 
• Leading quarterly and annual financial meetings with center leadership. 
• Advising Center leadership on tradeoffs among various expense options. 
• Developing tools for assessing viability of the Center’s financial commitments and the tradeoffs that result from those commitments. 
• Serving as a liaison between principal investigators and the Research Management Group (RMG) and Office of Sponsored Research (OSR) by managing the internal pre-award process (including budget development and proposal submission) and post-award sponsored funding. 
• Approving Center’s financial transactions, including iJournals, reimbursements, labor distributions and adjustments, and invoice payments. 
• Ensuring compliance with federal, state and university policies and procedures. Financial Analyst Children's Hospital Boston June 2009  –  January 2013  (3 years 8 months) Greater Boston Area 1. Manage departmental finance and grants portfolio comprising of Federal & Non-Federal funds for the largest pediatric ophthalmology department in the US - with 30 full-time faculty / practitioners and 7 full-time research faculty.  
 
2. Manage multi-million dollar endowment portfolio comprising of philanthropic and other special purpose funds, including 7 endowed chairs. 
 
3. Lead finance special projects for $16M Childrens Hospital Ophthalmology Foundation (CHOF). (e.g. HR compensation anlaysis for cost optimization) 
 
4. Member of committee directing process and technology driven transformation using Oracle/Peoplesoft for grants management. 
 
5. Lead investment analysis presentations to the Board & Finance Committees. 
 
 
- Familiarity with NIH, NSF rules / regulations and current issues in Healthcare Finance. 
- Collaborate very closely with Office of Sponsored Programs, Research Finance, Accounting, HR, Purchasing, Office of the Director for Finance, and The Childrens Hospital Trust at the hospital level.
